title: World's most asked questions: how can I get rid of the hiccups?

multiple-choice.question: What is a hiccup, and what causes it?

options.label: A
options.text: A hiccup is a voluntary contraction of the diaphragm that causes it to expand suddenly.

options.label: B
options.text: A hiccup is an involuntary spasm of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly.

options.label: C
options.text: A hiccup is a sudden closure of the vocal folds that causes the "hic" sound.

options.label: D
options.text: A hiccup is a result of swallowing too much air.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the vagus nerve in relation to hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: The vagus nerve regulates the heartbeat and breathing, and stimulating it can help stop hiccups.

options.label: B
options.text: The vagus nerve controls the diaphragm and causes hiccups when it is stimulated.

options.label: C
options.text: The vagus nerve has no relation to hiccups.

options.label: D
options.text: The vagus nerve helps to increase carbon dioxide levels in the bloodstream.

multiple-choice.question: How does swallowing a teaspoon of sugar help to get rid of hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: The sugar provides energy for the diaphragm to relax.

options.label: B
options.text: The act of gulping down the sugar provides a confusing stimulus for the vagus nerve.

options.label: C
options.text: The sugar helps to increase carbon dioxide levels in the bloodstream.

options.label: D
options.text: The sugar has no effect on hiccups.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of holding your breath or breathing into a paper bag to get rid of hiccups?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase oxygen levels in the bloodstream.

options.label: B
options.text: To decrease carbon dioxide levels in the bloodstream.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase carbon dioxide levels in the bloodstream and signal the diaphragm to relax.

multiple-choice.question: According to the SciShow survey, what is the most preferred method for relieving hiccups?

title: How do you know if you have a virus? - Cella Wright

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) testing in diagnosing viral infections?

options.label: A
options.text: To detect the presence of antibodies in the body

options.label: B
options.text: To amplify genetic information to detect the virus's genetic material

options.label: C
options.text: To identify the type of virus causing the infection

options.label: D
options.text: To determine the severity of the infection

multiple-choice.question: What type of genetic information is targeted by PCR testing?
What is the main difference between IgM and IgG antibodies in the context of immunoassays?

options.label: A
options.text: IgM antibodies are more abundant than IgG antibodies

options.label: B
options.text: IgM antibodies indicate a recent infection, while IgG antibodies indicate a past infection

options.label: C
options.text: IgM antibodies are more reliable in diagnosing current infections than IgG antibodies

options.label: D
options.text: IgG antibodies are only produced in response to a new infection

multiple-choice.question: How do immunoassays detect the presence of virus-specific antibodies in a sample?

options.label: C
options.text: Through a change in pH levels

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential use of blood plasma from individuals who have developed immunity to a virus?

options.label: A
options.text: As a treatment for people who are currently fighting the virus

options.label: B
options.text: As a vaccine against the virus

options.label: C
options.text: As a diagnostic tool for detecting the virus

options.label: D
options.text: As a way to prevent the spread of the virus

title: Why do bats carry so many diseases? (like coronavirus)

multiple-choice.question: What is a common factor among the viruses Nipah, Hendra, Ebola, Marburg, and SARS?

options.label: A
options.text: They are all carried by mosquitoes.

options.label: B
options.text: They are all carried by bats.

multiple-choice.question: Why do bats appear to carry more human-killing diseases than other animals?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they have a weak immune system.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they live in isolation from other animals.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they roost together in huge numbers and close quarters, helping viruses spread between individuals and species.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they have a short lifespan.

multiple-choice.question: What may be the reason bats are resilient to infection?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to produce reactive waste products that damage DNA.

options.label: B
options.text: Their ability to fly, which requires producing a lot of energy and leveling-up their in-flight DNA damage repair kits and other defenses.

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to live in cold climates.

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to hibernate during winter.

multiple-choice.question: How do some viruses survive the high internal temperatures of bats during flight?

options.label: B
options.text: By evolving to tolerate the heat.

options.label: D
options.text: By mutating into a different strain.

multiple-choice.question: What is suggested as a possible solution to control the spread of diseases carried by bats?

options.label: B
options.text: Leaving bats alone and trying to control the spread of diseases carried by humans.

options.label: C
options.text: Developing vaccines against all bat-borne diseases.

options.label: D
options.text: Creating bat sanctuaries to isolate them from humans.

title: Why don't haircuts hurt?

multiple-choice.question: Why doesn't it hurt to cut your hair?

options.label: A
options.text: Because hair is very thin and doesn't have much feeling.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the nerves in your hair are very small and don't send pain signals.

options.label: C
options.text: Because there are no nerves inside your hair.

options.label: D
options.text: Because haircuts are very quick and don't give your body time to feel pain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main job of nerves in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To help you move your muscles.

options.label: B
options.text: To help you sense the world around you.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when you touch something and it activates the nerves in your skin?

options.label: A
options.text: The nerves send a message to your muscles to move.

options.label: B
options.text: The nerves send a message to your brain to decode.

options.label: C
options.text: The nerves send a message to your heart to beat faster.

options.label: D
options.text: The nerves send a message to your stomach to digest food.

multiple-choice.question: Why can you feel your fingers touching the top of your head, but not your hair feeling your fingers?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the skin on your head has nerves, but your hair doesn't.

options.label: B
options.text: Because your fingers are more sensitive than your hair.

options.label: C
options.text: Because your head is more sensitive than your fingers.

options.label: D
options.text: Because your hair is too thin to feel anything.

multiple-choice.question: What is another part of the body that, like hair, doesn't have nerves and doesn't feel pain when cut?

title: Why is my leg asleep?

multiple-choice.question: What is the "pins and needles" feeling that people sometimes experience in their arms or legs?

options.label: A
options.text: A feeling of numbness that never goes away

options.label: B
options.text: A feeling of tingling or prickling that happens when blood flow is restored to a numb area

options.label: C
options.text: A feeling of pain that happens when you sit in one position for too long

options.label: D
options.text: A feeling of weakness that happens when you don't exercise enough

multiple-choice.question: Why do arms or legs sometimes "fall asleep"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are not getting enough oxygen

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not getting enough blood flow

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are not getting enough exercise

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not getting enough rest

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the nerves in an arm or leg when it "falls asleep"?

options.label: A
options.text: They start working harder to compensate for the lack of blood flow

options.label: B
options.text: They stop working because they are not getting enough blood flow

options.label: C
options.text: They start sending false signals to the brain

options.label: D
options.text: They become more sensitive to touch

multiple-choice.question: How can you prevent getting "pins and needles" in your arms or legs?

options.label: A
options.text: By sitting in one position for long periods of time

options.label: C
options.text: By making sure you don't sit or lean in one position for too long

options.label: D
options.text: By taking medication to improve blood flow

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the "pins and needles" feeling after a few minutes?

options.label: A
options.text: It gets worse and becomes more painful

options.label: B
options.text: It stays the same and doesn't change

options.label: C
options.text: It goes away as the nerves return to normal

options.label: D
options.text: It spreads to other parts of the body
